loans.name: Komiljon

texts.ru: Комилчон родился в 1952 года в сельской местности. Он с детства всегда мечтал стать врачом. Комилчон осуществил свою мечту. Он более 38 лет работает врачом в больнице своего района. Комилчон женат. Ее жена работает медсестрой в больнице. Они имеют 3 детей. Его сын учится в Медицинском Университете в Российской Федерации. Комилчон очень рад, что его сын выбрал его профессию. Комилчон запрашивает займ на сумму 2250 долларов США для оплаты учебного договора. Он имеет маленькую зарплату и не в состоянии оплатить за учебу сына. Он ждет вашу доброту и надеется на ваше милосердие.
texts.en:
Komiljon was born in 1952 in a village. Since childhood he dreamed of becoming a doctor. Komiljon realized his dream. He has worked as a doctor at a hospital in his region for more than 38 years. 

Komiljon is married. His wife works as a nurse at the hospital. They have three children. Their son studies at a Medical University in the Russian Federation. Komiljon is very happy that his son chose the same profession as him. 

Komiljon requests a loan in the amount of 2,250 US dollar to pay his son's tuition. He has a small pay and is not in a situation where he can pay for his son's education. He awaits your kindness and hopes for your charity.

loans.use: To pay for his son’s education

loans.name: Buenerge

texts.es:
Buenarge, invierte en el cultivo de maíz y frijol, ya que es una actividad que ejerce desde hace mucho tiempo y le genera los ingresos necesarios para salir adelante, en está ocasión necesita comprar abono, insecticidas y herbicidas, para preparar el terreno donde sembrara. Anteriormente él invirtió y tuvo una cosecha muy abundante y de buena calidad, cumplió con las necesidades de sus clientes a tiempo.
Como su economía mejoro notablemente pudo ampliar su vivienda y darle apoyo a su hija en sus estudios.
texts.en:
Buenerge earns a living by growing corn and beans. He has been doing this for a long time and it provides him with enough income to get ahead. 

This time around, he needs to purchase fertilizer, insecticides, and herbicides to preparing the land for sowing. 

His previous loan allowed him to have an abundant and high-quality crop, and he was able to fulfill his clients' requests on time. Since his economic situation increased notably, he was able to expand his home, and support his daughter in her studies.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, insecticides, and herbicides.

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Marcerine

texts.en:
Marcerine is married with seven children. She would like to use this Kiva loan to buy fertilizer to use for maize production; she needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer for use during maize production

loans.name: Seda

texts.en:
Seda is a private entrepreneur from the village Ayntap of Ararat region. She lives with her daughter and two sons. Seda's daughter works in the postal service, and her sons are employed in the private sector. All the family members put their efforts together to be able to earn a living. 

Seda runs a small local store where she sells different grocery products and household goods of daily demand. The assortment of goods she sells in the store is not that big. It needs to be updated and expanded periodically in order for her small business to develop in a sustainable way. 

Seda currently needs a loan of USD 3,000 to purchase new items to resell in her store. With the help of the loan, her small store will become more compatible. Seda and her family members will highly appreciate the lenders support, and will be grateful to them for their help in collecting the needed loan.

loans.use: to purchase new items to resell in her store.

loans.name: Karen

texts.en:
A hardworking and enterprising woman, Karen, who lives in the coastal region of Kenya, operates a chemist shop. In business for the past two years, she says that price fluctuations are her major challenge. 

With this Kshs 25,000 loan, Karen wants to purchase antibiotics and other medicines for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase antibiotics and other medicines for resale

loans.name: Erjanik

texts.en:
Erjanik is an experienced farmer from Haykadzor village of the Shirak region. She lives with her husband, son, and two daughters. With the help of her family, Erjanik is extensively involved in cattle breeding, in aviculture, in breeding a livestock of sheep, in beekeeping, and in cultivation of wheat. Her husband and sons sell the agricultural products in the local market, which is the main source of income for the family. 

As the autumn is progressing Erjanik needs to buy a supply of forage for the livestock. She needs a loan of  $2,000 to purchase the forage. The loan will help the family prepare their agribusiness for the winter. As this is Erjanik’s first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who didn’t have access to credit products before, because they have no credit history. Erjanik and her family will be very thankful to the lenders for the good will and will highly appreciate their support.

loans.use: to purchase forage for her livestock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a truck to start a transportation business.

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianney

texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianney is 33 years old. He is married with one child aged one. He would like to use his Kiva loan to buy fertilizers to use during rice production; he needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilzers for use during maize production.

loans.name: Mehrali

texts.en:
Mehrali is 20 years of age and is a young client. Mehrali is an IDP person (internally displaced person). He moved from the city of Fuzuli and now lives in the Bilasuvar region with his parents. He is a very positive and hardworking man. 

Mehrali is a merchant; he is selling mixed goods such as toys, household goods, perfumes and jewelry. He has two years experience in this business. 

As you can see from the photo, there are very few goods in his store because he does not have enough funds to buy goods. Even though it’s a small business, he has a lot of customers. Considering the customers’ demand, Mehrali wants to expand his business. For this reason he is applying for a loan of 1,800 AZN to buy new perfumes, toys and household goods for his store. He is very optimistic about this business and he awaits your support.

loans.use: to buy new perfumes toys and household goods for his store.

loans.name: Eldeniz

texts.en:
Eldeniz is 24 year old young client from Bilasuvar. He is not married. Eldeniz is an IDP person (internally displaced person). He moved from the city of Fuzuli and now lives in the Bilasuvar region with his parents. After several attempts to find a job he decided to start his own business. He is farmer and has raised seasonal fruits and vegetables for the last four years. He also breeds cattle.

He chose this business because it is profitable and fresh crops are in high demand. Eldeniz sells his crops in the central bazaar. His monthly income is 100 AZN. His father actively helps him to raise the crops.

As his products are in high demand, he  wants to expand his business and produce more fruits and vegetables to cover market demand. For this purpose he applied for a loan of 1,800 AZN. He will buy new garden tools, seeds and fertilizers. This is going to be his first loan.

loans.use: to buy new garden tools, seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Awa's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe est créé depuis décembre 2009.Il est composé de membres issus du même village,elles ont comme activité le petit commerce et l'agriculture.

Celle qui se trouve au milieu de la photo et levant le bras ,est la responsable du groupe,elle est âgée de 30ans,est mariée et mére de 04 enfants dont  un garçon.

Son activité est le commerce du mil et du maïs,elle affirme qu'elle posséde une bonne expérience par rapport à son activité.

Avec le prêt reçu,elle compte acheter du maïs pour une valeur de 30000f et de l'arachide pour une valeur de 20000f.

Son objectif est d'augmenter son épargne et assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en: This group was created in December 2009. It is made up of members from the same village. They make money through small business and agriculture. The one who is in the middle of the photo raising her hand is the leader of the group. She is 30 years old, married and the mother of four children, of which one is a boy. She makes money through the sale of millet and corn. She can confirm that she possesses good experience vis-a-vis her business. With the loan she receives, she expects to buy corn at a value of 30,000 f and peanuts at a value of 20,000 f. Her objective is to increase her savings and ensure her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase corn and peanuts.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.es: Doña concepción de 60 años de edad habita en casa de su propiedad junto con su esposo y sus dos hijos, ella se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir. El negocio está ubicado en su casa de habitación. Concepción es una mujer increíble y muy ejemplar  ya que es muy trabajadora, responsable y positiva, además, muchas personas dan buenas referencias de su persona y de su trabajo. Elabora variedad de prendas de vestir  a precios muy accesibles. También ofrece calidad en su trabajo, razón por la cual muchas personas la prefieren. Tiene muchos años de dedicarse a esta actividad por lo que ya cuenta con mucha experiencia y sobre todo con clientes fijos que cada día la prefieren más. Ha tomado la decisión de solicitar este crédito a INTEGRAL para  invertir en su pequeño negocio en la compra de los insumos necesarios como: telas, hilos, elástico, agujas,  etc. para la elaboración de variedad de prendas de vestir. Todo esto lo hace con el fin de dar un mejor servicio a los clientes de tal forma que los clientes se sientan motivados a seguir solicitando sus servicios y así sus ventas e ingresos se vean incrementados. Espera lograr su objetivo y mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Concepción, 60, lives in her own house with her husband and her two children.  She's an incredible and very exemplary woman because she's hardworking, responsible, and positive.  Many people highly recommend her and her work.

Concepción earns a living making clothing.  Her business is located in her house.  She makes a variety of garments at very affordable prices.  Her work is also high quality, which is why many people prefer her.  She has done this work for many years, so she has a lot of experience and steady customers who prefer her.

Concepción decided to request this loan from Integral to invest in her small business and buy fabric, thread, elastic, needles, and other supplies so she can make a variety of garments.

She's doing this to give her customers better service so they're motivated to keep on requesting her services and so her sales and income will grow.  She hopes to realize her goal and improve her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy fabric, thread, elastic, needles, etc.

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is 45 years old. He is married with three children. With the Kiva loan, he would like to buy fertilizers to use during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for use during maize production.

loans.name: Lala

texts.en:
Lala is a private entrepreneur from Kapan city. She lives with her husband, nine-year-old daughter and five-year-old son. Lala's husband works as a car mechanic. To assist her husband in earning a living, Lala runs a small local shop, where she sells clothes and shoes. The assortment of goods she sells in her store is not that big and needs to be updated and expanded periodically in order for her small business to develop and function in a productive way. 

Lala needs a loan of USD 1,500 to purchase new items (clothes and shoes) to resell in her store. She has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately wasn't able to pay it back. However, thanks to her hard work during recent times, Lala was able to run her small business in a sustainable way, ensuring that she will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, she has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. 

Lala and her family will be thankful to all the lenders for helping them maintain their small business.

loans.use: to purchase new items (clothes and shoes) to resell in her store.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 26 years old. He has requested this Kiva loan to buy fertilizers to increase his production of rice. Vincent wishes to reinvest profits into his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for use during rice production.

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is 36 years old, a female and married. She has five children 18,16,14,12 and five years old who she supports. She was introduced to KADET Ltd. by a KADET officer and she has a canteen. She has been in this business for thirteen years; it is located at Gongoni. 

In her business she earns a monthly income of KES 13,050. She is taking his fourth loan of KES 40,000 which she intends to use to add stock to her  business by adding stocks of milk, bread, sugar, salt, wheat flour, maize flour, soft drinks, cooking oil and rice. Her previous loan of KES 30,000 was paid back successfully.

Khadija  will use the anticipated profit to expand her business by making it into a wholesale shop. Her hopes and dreams for her future business and family are to open another business and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase milk, bread, sugar, salt, wheat flour, maize flour, soft drinks, cooking oil and rice to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 46 years old. He would like to use his Kiva loan to buy fertilizers to use during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for use during rice production.

With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for use during rice production.

loans.name: Simeon

texts.en:
Simeon is 61 years old. He would like to use a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for use during rice production

loans.name: Margarit

texts.en:
Margarit is from Sisian city, Syuniq region. She lives with her husband and works as a music teacher. Her salary, however, is not enough to cover her family's basic needs. With the help of her husband she is engaged in cattle breeding and in cultivation of wheat, potatoes, apples, pears, and walnuts. Margarit's husband helps her greatly in selling the agricultural products in the local market. 

As life is getting more expensive with time, Margarit wants to expand her agribusiness a little bit to be able to more effectively meet her family's needs. A loan of USD 3,000 will be a huge support to this hard-working woman enabling her to purchase a cow, two calves, and four piglets, to buy forage for the livestock and to purchase some fuel for agricultural machinery. 

As this is Margarit’s first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who didn’t have access to credit products before, because they have no credit history. The family will be very thankful to the lenders for their good-will and support.

loans.use: to purchase a cow, two calves, and four piglets, to buy forage for the livestock and to purchase some fuel for agricultural machinery.

loans.name: Jalal

texts.en:
Jalal is a 23-year-old single Palestinian refugee, working and living in a Palestinian Camp with limited access to several living and working sectors.

Jalal is well known in his region and has a good reputation for the hard work he has done to develop his living standards and his business with the aim of improving his socioeconomic situation. Four years ago, he opened his own internet cafe, where most of the camps' teenagers and citizens come and spend a joyful time with each other, since it is a major sector for entertainment in a place that lacks such similar things.

Jalal is a acquiring a Youth loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, to do the necessary maintenance on his business equipment, to keep his business up to date. He'll also use part of the loan to do necessary maintenance on his car, which he uses to buy requested equipment from outside the camp and the nearby villages.

He hopes that in the future, he'll be capable of opening a wider business outside the camp and attracting more customers.

loans.use: to do necessary maintenance on his business equipment.

loans.name: Raul Ignacio

texts.es:
Raul vive en la ciudad de Imperial, trabaja como profesor en un colegio de su ciudad desde hace 3 años, con el fruto de su trabajo puede salir adelante y poder apoyar con algunos gastos del hogar; Raul tiene mucha paciencia para poder enseñar y por ello cree que le va viene n su trabajo.

Raul está agradecido con los prestamistas kiva ya que gracias a la ayuda que le han brindado el podrá comprar materiales de construcción para poder construir un cuarto para su madre y de esta manera mejorar su calidad de vida y seguir esforzándose para hacer realidad su sueño:” Poder estudiar una maestría y apoyar a su familia”.
texts.en: Raul lives in the city of Imperial. He has worked as a teacher at a school in his city for the past three years. With the fruits of his labor, he can move forward and meet some of his household expenses. Raul has a lot of patience to be able to teach and this is why he believes that things are going well for him in his work. Raul is thankful to the Kiva lenders, because thanks to the help they provide, he will be able to buy construction materials to build a room for his mother. This way, he will improve their quality of life and keep working to make his dream a reality: "To be able to get a Master's degree and support his family."

loans.use: to buy construction materials.

loans.name: Transito Edenilson

texts.es:
Tránsito, se está preparando para sembrar y como es un hombre con mucha experiencia sabe que es mejor contar con todo lo necesario para evitar algún problema, por lo que invertirá en la compra de abono, insecticidas, herbicidas y también invertirá un poco en la crianza de ganado.
Con el préstamo que se le dio antes fortaleció su negocio de cultivo de granos básicos y crianza de ganado, tuvo las ganancias que le dan la oportunidad de cumplir con el compromiso de la deuda y sobre todo darle a su familia mejor alimentación, salud y educación.
texts.en: Transito is preparing to plant his seeds and, as someone with a lot of experience, he knows its better to have everything that he needs so as to avoid any problems.  So, he is going to invest in buying manure, insecticides, and herbicides, and invest a little in raising cattle.  Transito used his previous loan to strengthen his business growing basic grains and raising cattle.  He earned profits that allow him to pay off his debt and, above all to provide his family with better food, health and education.

loans.use: to buy manure, insecticides, and herbicides.

loans.name: Ana Hilda

texts.es: Doña Ana de 48 años de edad vive en casa propia con su madre y sus hermano, ella se dedica a la venta de cereales como frijoles, arroz, maíz, etc. desde hace varios años, posee clientela fija que la buscan y la refieren por la calidad del producto y los buenos precios, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, doña Ana está solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas cereales por mayor y así seguir  con su negocio que le genera buenas ganancias y poder tener una mejor estabilidad económica junto con su familia
texts.en: Ana is 40 years old and lives in her own house with her mother and siblings,  Ana has been making a living selling cereals, such as beans, rice, corn, and more for some years.  She has a number of fixed customers who come looking for her and send her more customers because of the quality and good prices of her products.  With her profits, Ana is able to cover some household costs.  Ana is applying for a loan in order to buy more cereals in bulk and thus to continue with her business.  The business is giving her good profits and she will be able to have more financial stability alongside her family.

loans.use: to buy cereals such as beans, rice, corn, and more, in bulk.

loans.name: Celestin

texts.en:
Celestin, age 22, is a rice farmer. He would like to request a Kiva loan in order to buy fertilizers for his rice field so that he can increase his production. With the expected increase in his profits, he will further invest in his farming business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors, which will enhance his farming capacity. Celestin and his wife have one child. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37 percent of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65 percent of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90 percent of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for his rice field

loans.name: Narcisse

texts.en:
Narcisse, age 35, is a rice farmer. He would like to request a Kiva loan in order to buy fertilizers for his rice field so that he can increase his production. With the expected increase in his profits, he will further invest in his farming business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors, which will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37 percent of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65 percent of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90 percent of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for his rice field

loans.name: Lindomar

texts.es:
Lindomar, está surtiendo su inventario y necesita capital para comprar madera por mayor y luego vendarla a sus clientes. Cuando se le facilito el crédito anterior lo invirtió en el negocio y cubrió por mucho tiempo los pedidos de sus clientes; él estuvo percibiendo ganancias que antes no tenía pero que necesitaba, ha saldado deudas y su negocio sigue creciendo.
Sigue esmerándose para que sus hijos tengan una educación de calidad y lleguen hacer profesionales.
texts.en:
Lindomar is stocking up and needs capital to buy wood in bulk, which he can later sell to his customers.  Lindomar was given a previous loan that was he invested in his business and, for a long time, fulfilled his customers' orders.  Lindomar earn higher profits than ever before.  He needed these profits and paid off his debts, and his business continues to grow.  

Lindomar continues to go to great efforts to ensure his children receive a quality education so that they can later become professionals.

loans.use: to buy wood in bulk.

loans.name: Al-Ettihad 50065 Group

texts.en:
Zahiya, age 75, is the featured borrower of the Al-ettihad 50065 Group. She earns an income by offering tailoring services. She has been engaged in this work for the past 30 years. She is a hard worker whose goal is to help support her husband and family through her business. She is known in the community for her special talent in the tailoring domain. Zahiya and her husband have one child.

Zahiya is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to perform necessary maintenance on her house before the winter season sets in. Her goal is to keep it a healthy place for her family to live in and for her customers to visit. She hopes to stay in good health so that she can remain capable of responding both to her family's and to her customers' needs.

Zahiya and the other group members joined together to acquire a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua because they have always been neighbors and friends. Zahiya is second from the left in the picture. The other members are named Yousra, Najwa, and Jinan. Yousra is shown holding her precious baby, Najwa is the first on the left (wearing pink), and Jinan is at the far right.

loans.use: to perform necessary maintenance on her house before the winter season sets in

loans.name: Zenab

texts.en:
Zenab, age 28, operates a retail store business to earn an income. Her store is located at Zhogeto. She has been engaged in this business for the past four years. She earns a monthly income of KSH 11,760. Zenab and her husband support four children, ages five, seven, 10, and 12. 

Zenab was introduced to KADET Ltd by a KADET officer. Her previous loan of KSH 25,000 was paid back successfully. She is now requesting her second loan in the amount of KSH 40,000. She intends to use her loan funds to add necessary stock to her business, such as toothpaste, bathing soap, toothbrushes, bread, sugar, salt, wheat flour, maize flour, cooking oil, and rice. 

Zenab will use the anticipated profits to expand her business by turning it into a wholesale shop. Her hopes and dreams for her future business and family are to open another business and to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy toothpaste, bathing soap, toothbrushes, bread, sugar, salt, wheat flour, maize flour, cooking oil, and rice to offer for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy construction materials such as metal sheeting and beams.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima has operated a shoe selling business to earn a living and support her family. The previous loan helped her to buy more stock of shoes and here again she comes to you requesting a loan of KES 40,000 to buy second hand clothes to sell to supplement her income. She is appreciative of the support.

loans.use: to buy second hand clothes to sell to supplement her income.

loans.name: Gaspard

texts.en:
Gaspard is 42 years old. He is married with six children between the ages of 2 and 16. He has spent five years in rice production. 

He would like to use the Kiva loan to buy fertilizer during rice production;  he needs fertilizer to increase production. 

With the profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future, he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer to use during rice production

loans.name: Rosylyne

texts.en:
Rosylyne is married and has three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are household consumables and fees for her children.

For over six years, Rosylyne has operated a tailoring business, making garments for both men and women. She cites seasonality as her major challenge and she dreams of establishing a boutique in the near future.

With the KES 20,000, Rosylyne wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing threads for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing threads for her business.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a married Iraqi client who is 54 years old and has four children, for whom he works hard to provide all by himself.

Ali owns a small shop where he sells women's and children's clothing. He has a lot of experience in this field; when he was in his youth, he used to work as an employee at a similar shop. In 2009, he established his own business. Ali's fame spread all around the city, and he is well known, with an excellent reputation.

Ali is requesting a loan of 2,400 USD. He will use this loan to pay the annual rent of his shop, and to renovate it with modern decorations. 

Ali is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he may be able to educate his children and provide for his family's needs.

loans.use: to pay the annual rent of his shop, and to renovate it with modern decorations

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en:
Anahit is an experienced farmer from Noravan village of the Armavri region. She lives with her brother and his wife. 

To take care of her family's needs, Anahit is engaged in cattle breeding, in agriculture, in breeding livestock of sheep and pigs, and in cultivation of alfalfa and grass, which serves as forage for the livestock. Anahit's family members help her greatly in her daily farming activities; her brother sells the agricultural products in the local market. 

Anahit and her family own barns in the Gegharquniq region. They breed the cattle there during the summer, and return back in autumn. As the autumn is progressing, Anahit needs to purchase a winter supply of forage for the livestock. 

A loan of USD 3,000 will assist her greatly in purchasing forage for the livestock, and to make previous credit payments. 

As this is Anahit’s first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who didn’t have access to credit products before, because they have no credit history. 

The family will be very thankful to the lenders for their goodwill and support in collecting the needed loan.

loans.use: to purchase forage for the livestock, and to make previous credit payments

loans.name: Edik

texts.en:
Edik is an experienced agronomist from Aragats village of the Armavir region. He lives with his daughter. To take care of his family's needs, Edik is engaged in cultivation of potatoes, cucumbers and greens. He sells the agricultural products in the local market, which is the only source of the family's income. 

To continue running his agribusiness in a sustainable way, Edik needs a loan of USD 2,000 to purchase cellophane and cables for building a greenhouse for plant cultivation and to buy potato seeds. He has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before but unfortunately wasn't able to return it back. However, thanks to hard work during the recent times, Edik was able to run his agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that he will be able to cover the monthly payments. He has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Edik and his daughter will highly appreciate the lenders support and will be thankful to them for their good will.

loans.use: to purchase cellophane and cables for building a greenhouse for plant cultivation and to buy potato seeds.

loans.name: Donatile

texts.en:
Donatile is 30 years old; she is married with four children. 

She would like to use the Kiva loan to buy fertilizer during rice production; she needs to buy fertilizer to increase production. 

With the profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future, she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer to use during rice production.

loans.name: Haydar

texts.en:
Haydar is a hard-working 27-years-old Iraqi client. He is married and the father of 2 children. Haydar is the sole provider of his family.

Haydar owns a barber shop. He established his business in 2010 and has gained much experience in this field. Haydar is well-known in the surrounding area thanks to his good customer care and his affordable prices.

Haydar is applying for a youth loan of 2,400 USD. The aim of this loan is to buy 2 new hair-cutting chairs, install a display window and install signage for his barber shop. Haydar is aiming to grow his business even more and increase his profits so he may be able to provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: to buy 2 new hair-cutting chairs, install a display window and install signage for his barber shop.

loans.name: Celestin

texts.en:
Celestin is 33 years old. He would like to use a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers for use during rice production.

loans.name: Luís Antonio

texts.es:
Luis de 45 años, estudio hasta 4to grado, procede de una familia de 8 hermanos. Actualmente vive con su madre y un hermano más,  su papá falleció hace ya muchos años.  

Luis, está soltero y trabaja arduamente para el sustento de su madre y de él .Sus otro hermanos viven en diferentes hogares con sus respectivas parejas. 

Tiene 20 años de dedicarse a la venta de Jarcia (machete y cumas), también vende hamaca ambas actividades las aprendió de sus padres, pues ellos se dedicaban a eso.

El crédito que está solicitando, lo distribuirá $ 250.00 en compra de hamacas de cascarilla para revenderlas, otros $250.00 en compra de cumas, ambas productos serán para comercializarlos en una ciudad.  Él posee mucha experiencia en el desarrollo de esta actividad y le es muy rentable. Él pretende incrementar sus inventarios y poder ofrecerles más variedad a  sus clientes  vender más para generar más ingresos.

Luis sueña tener su local propio y ahí poder vender sus productos, también desea construir su  casa. Con la ganancia  que le generen las ventas, pretende cancelar las cuotas del crédito y así incrementar su inventario y tener más  ingresos y mejorar la calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Luis, 45, studied through the fourth grade.  He comes from a family of eight siblings.  Currently he lives with his mother and another brother.  His father died many years ago.  Luis is single and works hard to support himself and his mother.  His other siblings live in different houses with their respective spouses.

Luis has earned a living selling machetes and knives for 20 years.  He also sells hammocks.  He learned both jobs from his parents, who earned a living doing this work.

Luis will use $250 from the loan he's requesting to buy corn husk hammocks for resale and another $250 to buy machetes to sell in another city.  He has a lot of experience in this job and it's very profitable for him.  He plans to increase his inventory and sell a greater variety to his customers so he earns more income.

Luis dreams of having his own store where he can sell his products.  He also wants to build a house.  With the profits from his sales he plans to pay off the loan and increase his inventory so he can earn more income and improve his quality of life.

loans.use: to buy corn husk hammocks and knives

loans.name: Artur

texts.en:
Arthur is a farmer from the Nor Kesaria village of the Armavir region. He lives with his wife and two-year-old daughter. His wife works in the village secondary school. Her salary is so low that she cannot afford a living based on that salary alone. 

To cover his family's needs, Arthur is engaged in cattle breeding, and in plant cultivation. He cultivates onions, melon, and alfalfa, and sells the agricultural products in the local market. 

To sustain his agribusiness, Arthur needs a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase some forage for cattle, and to buy onion seeds. He has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately, wasn't able to repay it. 

However, thanks his recent hard work, Arthur was able to run his agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that he will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, he has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history, and have no access to credit products. 

Arthur and his family will be thankful to all the lenders and will highly appreciate their support.

loans.use: to purchase some forage for cattle, and to buy onion seeds

loans.name: Manyak

texts.en:
Manyak is an experienced farmer from Masis village of the Ararat region. She lives with her husband, son, and brother-in-law. Manyak's son works in the police, but his salary is not enough to cover the family's needs. To be able to meet her family's needs, Manyak is engaged in cattle breeding, aviculture, and the cultivation of alfalfa, apricots and walnuts. Her husband and brother-in-law sell the agricultural products in the local market. 

To continue running her agribusiness in a sustainable way, Manyak needs to make some investments. She needs a loan of USD 3,000 to expand and renovate the barn and to purchase a cow. She has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before but unfortunately wasn't able to return it back. However, thanks to hard work during the recent times, Manyak was able to run her agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that she will be able to cover the monthly payments of a loan. She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Manyak and her family will be thankful to all the lenders for helping them to maintain and develop their agribusiness.

loans.use: to expand and renovate the barn and to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Mkrtich

texts.en:
Mkrtich is an experienced farmer from Aghavnatun village of the Armavri region. He lives with his wife. 

To take care of their needs, Mkrtich and his wife are engaged in the cultivation of potatoes, cucumbers, greens, grapes and apples. He sells the agricultural products in the local market. This is the main source of the family's income. 

As their needs are growing day by day, Mkrtich needs to expand his agribusiness to be able to more effectively meet the family's needs. A loan of USD 2000 will be a great support to this hard-working man and will enable him to purchase cellophane and cables for building a greenhouse and purchase some fertilizers and potato seeds. The loan will help the family sustain their agribusiness. Mkrtich and his wife highly rely on the goodwill of the lenders and will be thankful to them for their support.

loans.use: to purchase cellophane and cables for building a greenhouse and purchase some fertilizers and potato seeds.

loans.name: Jaridini

texts.en:
Jaridini is 56 years old, a female and married. She has four (4) children, who are 18, 15, 13 and 10 years old whom she supports. She has a poultry business. She has been in this business for four years. In her business, she earns a monthly income of KES 10,850. 

Jaridini was introduced to KADET by a KADET officer. She is taking her third loan of KES 10,000 which she intends to use in adding stock to her business by adding chicks and poultry feed. Her previous loan of KES 30,000 was paid back successfully. Jaridini will use the anticipated profit to expand her business. Her hopes and dreams for her future business and family are to open another business and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more chicks and poultry feed.

loans.name: Ep Birema2 Group

texts.fr: La cliente  Banzi est une conseillère du collectif de crédit pour les  enseignants « Ep Birema2 »,  entrepreneur expérimentée, dynamique, âgée de 41 ans et mère de 3 enfants qui étudient tous. Son conjoint un aussi enseignant. La cliente est enseignante, mais aussi, elle vend des divers pour accroitre son revenu. Elle installe ses articles  à un point de vente animé de son quartier (au long de la rue). Elle commença ses affaires avec son fonds propre issu de son salaire.  Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’acheter les divers (2 sacs de sucres, 1 bidon d’huile de table, allumettes, 2 box de bonbons, 2 box de biscuits, 1 casier de Fanta, 1 carton de jus, 1 box de lotion, savon de toilette, 6 pièces de pagnes, 10 paires de souliers, etc.).  Ainsi, elle souhaite scolariser ses enfants, étendre son projet de commerce et construire une maison.   Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour l’autonomisation des femmes entrepreneurs enseignants non bancables, surtout ; pendant ce moment critique de guerre à l’Est du pays.
texts.en:
Banzi is the advisor of the borrowing group of teachers named "Ep Birema 2" and is an experienced entrepreneur. She is a dynamic 41-year-old mother of 3 children, all of whom attend school. Her husband is also a teacher.

In addition to teaching, Banzi also sells various items. She makes the sales from the shop she runs in her neighborhood, along the street. She began this business with her own funds earned from her salary. This new loan will allow her to purchase various items (2 bags of sugar, 1 barrel of table oil, matches, 2 boxes of candy, 2 boxes of biscuits, 1 case of Fanta, 1 carton of juice, 1 box of lotion, bath soap, 6 pieces of "pagne" cloth, 10 pairs of shoes, etc.)

As a result, Banzi would like to educate her children, expand her business offerings, and build a home. In closing, she sincerely thanks Hekima for enabling autonomy of female teacher entrepreneurs not eligible for traditional banking, especially during this critical time of war in the east of the country.

loans.use: to purchase various items (2 bags of sugar, 1 barrel of table oil, matches, 2 boxes of candy, 2 boxes of biscuits, 1 case of Fanta, 1 carton of juice, 1 box of lotion, bath soap, 6 pieces of "pagne" cloth, 10 pairs of shoes, etc.)

loans.name: Alexis

texts.en:
Alexis is 33 years old. He is married with four children. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. he needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is 40 years old. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Jean Bosco

texts.en:
Jean Bosco, age 37, is a rice farmer. He is requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy fertilizers to use during rice production. Investing in fertilizer will allow him to increase his crop production. With the expected profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. He and his wife have two children.
  
The agriculture sector accounts for 37 percent of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65 percent of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90 percent of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy  fertilizers for his rice field

loans.name: Jose Rafael

texts.es:
José, tiene 52 años, está casado, tiene tres hijos, ellos ya formaron su propia familia, vive solo con su esposa. Se dedica a cultivar granos básicos desde su niñez, oficio que aprendió de su padre y hoy lo practica con sus hijos. El crédito lo ocupara para compra de insumos agrícolas (insecticidas, herbicidas, abono), para preparar la tierra para la cosechar en época de verano.
 Con esto tendrá una cosecha abundante, mejores ingresos con los que pagara la deuda y mejorara su economía familiar; por su experiencia no se le hace difícil el trabajo.
Desea continuar trabajando la tierra para llevar el sustento diario a su hogar y ampliar su área de cultivo.
texts.en:
José, 52 years old, is married and has three children. His children have already formed their own families, so José lives alone with his wife. José has made a living growing basic grains since he was young. He learned this trade from his father and today he works alongside his own children. José will use this loan to buy farming supplies (insecticides, weedkiller, fertilizer) in order to prepare his land for sowing during the summer season. This will help him to produce an abundant crop, increase his earnings, pay off his debt, and improve his family's finances. 

Due to his experience, this work is not difficult for José. He desires to continue working the land in order to provide for his family and expand his land for growing.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies (insecticides, weedkiller, fertilizer)

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is 36 years old and lives in the West Point community which is the populated area in Montserrado County. She is living with her husband and four children between 6 and 19 years old. She did not attend school but she sells charcoal from a shop which she manages as well. These goods have been sold for the past 5 years without encountering any problem. Her mother assisted with some funds which she used to start her business. She is asking for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business in order to have some sustainable future plan.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Sumaira

texts.en:
Sumaira is a 25-year old married woman, living with her husband in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. 

Her husband provides services for troubleshooting refrigerators, air conditioners and dispancers. For his business from time to time he buys refrigeration accessories such as compressors, condensers, relays, overloads etc. to offer his valued customers. He buys all the accessories to offer his customers at an increased price. Mostly customers do not have awareness of product rates which is beneficial for increased profit margins. 

She requested a loan so that her husband could buy accessories such as compressors, condensers, relays, and overloads so that he can get maximum turnover.

Sumaira wishes for a bright future for her family and her dream is to provide a better education to her children.

She is very thankful to Kiva and its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy copper pipes, condensers, compressors, relays, overloads, etc for their refrigeration shop.

loans.name: Nahida

texts.en:
Nahida is a 35-year-old married mother of three children who has been working for the past twenty three years in the calligraphy and printing business with her husband. They run the business together in a well managed way. She also works on designing and printing Vinyl and flex signs and logos for companies.

She is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to buy a specialized technical cutter necessary to maintain a good quality of production.
She hopes to stay capable of developing and improving her business in a well manged way to keep up with the new released related technologies.

loans.use: To buy a specialized technical cutter

loans.name: Therese

texts.en:
Therese is 40 years old. She has four children between the ages of nine and 12. She would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and to buy fertilizers during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during the production of maize.

loans.name: Mikheil

texts.en:
Mikheil is 24 years old. He is married and has an infant child. His father lives with Mikheil as well. Mikheil is the only one who earns money in his household. He is a construction worker and works on house renovations. He earns a small daily salary. Mikheil is a very hard-working and enthusiastic young man who wishes to get ahead. 

In order to generate more income Mikheil decided to purchase a truck and work on firewood transportation in his free time. With the loan he hopes to receive, Mikheil will pay for the truck and start the new business. He will carry firewood from the forest, cut it and sell it among locals. His father will assist him in this business. A majority of Georgian villages use wood fuel for heating in the wintertime and now is the high season as people purchase supplies. Mikheil hopes he will earn a good income and ensure his family members with better living conditions. The family hopes for your kindness.

loans.use: to purchase a truck to transport firewood from the forest

loans.name: Asitu

texts.en:
Asitu, age 37, sells sugar, flour, and popcorn to earn an income. She lives with her husband and their three children in Sinkor, an area where the living conditions are much like those in the center of Monrovia. Asitu's husband is a tailor. Their youngest child is eight years old and the eldest is 16. The children live at home and attend school. Asitu herself never had the opportunity to receive an education.

Asitu has been engaged in her business for the past three years. She learned the trade from her mother. Her primary business obstacle is that sometimes her customers buy on credit and do not pay on time. She enjoys her business because it makes her self-sufficient. 

She is requesting a loan in order to purchase sugar, flour, and popcorn for her business. 

Her goal is to build a house for her family and to take good care of her children.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, flour, and popcorn to offer for sale

loans.name: Evys Catalino

texts.es: Evys, tiene 26 años de edad, está soltero y vive en el municipio de Choloma junto a su madre y una hermana. Evys trabaja en una maquila por 4 días a la semana y tiene su propia pulpería donde ofrece productos de la canasta básica como ser refrescos, carnes, embutidos, lácteos, harina,manteca, arroz, frijoles, maíz, café, azúcar, pan, etc. El negocio es administrado por su hermana los días que el trabaja en la maquila y los otros días lo administra el.  lleva dos años de tener el negocio y se ha mantenido bien. El préstamo que solicita es el tercer ciclo y es por 26,000 Lempiras el cual lo va invertir en la compra de  carnes, embutidos, lácteos, churros, granos básicos, azúcar, productos de aseo y otros para poder ofrecer más variedad de productos y poder aumentar las ventas. Su objetivo es ampliar su negocio y ayudar a su familia.
texts.en:
Evys, 26 years old, is single and lives in the municipality of Choloma with his mother and a sister.  Evys works in an assembly plant 4 days a week and has his own general store where he offers the products of the basic basket, such as soft drinks, meat, stuffings, milk products, flour, lard, rice, beans, corn, coffee, sugar, bread, etc. 

The business is administered by his sister on the days he works in the assembly plant, then he administers it on the other days. Evys has had the business for 2 years and it has done well. 

The loan Evys requests is part of his communal bank's 3rd cycle. It's for 26,000 Lempiras, which he will invest in purchasing meat, stuffing, milk products, fried bread sticks, basic grains, sugar, cleaning products and other items to be able to offer more product variety and to increase sales.

Evys objective is to expand his business and help his family.

loans.use: buy meat, stuffing, milk products, fried dough sticks, basic grains, sugar, cleaning products, and other items to sell.

loans.name: Maria Victorina

texts.es:
María, es madre soltera, tiene cuatro hijos, se dedica al comercio de frutas y verduras. Su negocio nació hace cuatro años,  lo atiende desde 8:00 a.m. hasta las 5:00 p.m., en sus inicios tenía muy poco producto que ofrecer, pero con la experiencia que ha ido ganando su negocio cada día está más surtido, para ella no ha sido difícil administrarlo ya que es apoyada por su hija mayor y ambas son las encargadas de mantenerlo activo.
Invertirá en la compra de repollo, zanahorias, manzanas, fresas, etc., y granos básicos (arroz, maíz y frijol), con esto ella estará ofreciendo nuevos productos al alcance de sus clientes, tendrá mayor rentabilidad, y más clientes satisfechos.
María sueña con salir de su deuda sin ninguna dificultad, seguir trabajando para cubrir todas las necesidades de sus hijos.
texts.en:
María is a single mother with four children. She makes a living selling fruits and vegetables. Her business began four years ago and she attends to it from 8 a.m. until 5 p.m. Initially she had very few products for sale, however her business has become more stable and better stocked with each passing day. It has not been difficult for her to manage it because her oldest daughter helps her and both are responsible for keeping it alive.

She will purchase cabbages, carrots, apples, strawberries, etc., as well as staples (rice, corn and beans). With this she will be offering new products to her customers. She will make more profits and have more satisfied customers.

María dreams of coming out of debt effortlessly and of continuing to work so that she can meet all of her children’s needs.

loans.use: to purchase cabbages, carrots, apples, strawberries, etc., and staples (rice, corn and beans).

loans.name: Maria Alicia

texts.es: Maria Alicia mayor de edad madre soltera con un hijo menor de edad, originaria del municipio de chinandega ubicado en el occidente del país, María es propietaria de un tramo de zapatos en uno de los mercados del municipio, donde ofrece diversos estilos de zapatos desde bebe, niños, jóvenes, adultos y ya avanzada la edad, como zapatos, de vestir, deportivos, casuales, sandalias, entre otros mas, ella compra al por mayor en otros municipios del país, al igual que en otras marcas exclusivas del país, inicia este negocio desde muy joven para apoyar con los gastos familiares en su hogar, negocio el cual aprende con su mama, dejandole este negocio mas adelante a ella cuando adquiere la mayoría de edad, y donde poco a poco ha logrado aumentar mas su inventario al igual que su clientela, uno de sus sueños es poder realizar ciertas mejoras en su hogar y así brindarle un techo digno donde vivir a su pequeño hijo, el cual también es otro de sus sueños verlo realizado en todo un profesional. el objetivo de este crédito es para capital de trabajo en la compra de diferentes estilos de zapatos aprovechando la temporada que se acerca y es donde las ventas son mayores.
texts.en:
María is of legal age. She is a single mother with a son who is a minor. María was born in the municipality of Chinandega, located in the western part of the country. She has a section in the municipal market from which she sells all kinds of shoes for babies, kids, young adults, adults, and the elderly. She sells dress shoes, sportswear, sandals, and many others. María buys shoes in bulk in other municipalities and also some brands that are exclusive to Nicaragua. María began her business when she was very young in order to help with her family's expenses. She learned the trade from her mother, who later left the business for her when she became of age. 

Little by little, María has succeeded in increasing her stock as well as her customers. One of her dreams is to be able to make some improvements on her home in order to provide her son with a dignified place to live. Another dream is to see her son become a professional. María's objective for this loan is to use the working capital to buy different styles of shoes, taking advantage of the approaching season, during which sales increase.

loans.use: to buy a variety of shoe styles such as: sportswear, dress shoes, sandals, casual shoes, and others.

loans.name: Zanoubia

texts.en:
Zanoubia, age 40 and divorced, works as an assistant in an association. She is the mother of three children, for whom she sacrifices her whole life in order to provide them with the best living conditions she can offer them. 

Zanoubia has been employed as an assistant for the past five years, and this is her only source of income. Her low earnings are not enough to cover her family's increasing needs, which is why she is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua. She will use her loan funds to pay for her children's increasing school tuition fees. 

Zanouba is well-known in her region. She has a good reputation and is respected for her hard work, both at her place of employment and within the community, especially since she is her family's sole breadwinner.
 
Her goal is to one day open her own children's daycare center. She intends to work hard to make her dream come true.  This will significantly improve her family's socioeconomic situation.

loans.use: To pay for her children school fees

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is a cattle farmer and trader. He has had a passion for being a cattle farmer since childhood but had always been financially limited since cows are somewhat expensive and require a lot of input to yield a profit.

Through a friend, however, he learned about UGAFODE's financial services to help the rural working poor and was impressed that he could get money even without security. Nicholas now needs money to buy more cows that he will graze and later sell at a profit. Nicholas is pictured in the photograph with a UGAFODE staff member in a white shirt (left to right).

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Kimsrong

texts.en:
Kimsrong, age 19 and unmarried, currently lives with her parents and siblings in Stueng Trang district, Kampong Cham province. She is a newly graduated student, having finished her high school level in the province. 

Kimsrong aims to continue her education and pursue a Bachelor's degree in accounting at Mekong University in Phnom Penh. She has a passion for her major because she realizes that accountants play an important role in the operation of every business, so the job market is strong and graduates are in high demand. 

Kimsrong’s education is subsidized by her parents, so during her course she plans to have a part-time job to help her parents cover her education costs.

Due to the family’s financial constraints, Kimsrong decided to acquire a loan of 1,100 US dollars to pay for her tuition fees and buy study materials to support her course. As it’s her first loan cycle, Kimsrong is committed to study hard because she realizes that an education will give her the opportunity to get a high-paying job that will allow her to support her parents when they get older. Her parents, though not pictured with her, will be her joint borrowers and will be responsible for making principal repayments on the loan. 

Kimsrong appreciates the help of people all around the world who have contributed their funds to programs like Kiva via its partner HKL, which will allow students from low-income families to continue their educations.

loans.use: to pay for her tuition fees and buy study materials to support her course

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy construction materials.

loans.name: Marine

texts.en:
Marine is an experienced farmer from Sisian city of the Syuniq region. She lives with her husband, son, and elderly, pensioner mother-in-law. Marine works in a kindergarten and her son is a contractual serviceman in the military. With their low salaries, however, they cannot afford a living. To be able to meet her family's needs, Marine is engaged in breeding a herd of sheep in addition to being involved in aviculture, pisciculture, and the cultivation of potatoes, apples, pears, and walnuts. Marine's husband helps her greatly in her everyday farming activities; he brings the agricultural products to the local market. 

To continue running her agribusiness in a sustainable way, Marine needs a loan of 3,000 USD to purchase twenty sheep and some feed for the livestock. As this is Marine’s first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF. The first chance loan program provides loans to people who haven't had access to credit products in the past because they have no credit history. Marine and her family will be very thankful to the lenders for their good will and support.

loans.use: to purchase twenty sheep and some feed for the livestock.

loans.name: Antoine

texts.en:
Antoine is 59 years old. He would like to use a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers for rice. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming Antoine wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers for use in rice cultivation.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for additional mobile phones and phone accessories.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok, 35, is married and has two children, one of whom is attending a local primary school. He is a farmer and owns a few pieces of land on which he grows rice to sell in the market in his area. Despite hardships, Sok aims to move his family forward and provide opportunities for education to his children. This has given him the strength to always advance, overcoming the various obstacles that have come up. He is requesting a loan to build a latrine for his family to use because his home doesn't currently have one. This will improve his family's living conditions, promote their health, and help to lessen environmental deterioration. He will use another portion of the loan to build a pigpen at his backyard, where he can keep a few pigs to raise. He is grateful for the loan granted through HKL because it has a much lower interest than other loan products.

loans.use: to build a latrine for his family to use.

loans.name: Kuwaytiya

texts.en:
Kuwaytiya is from Iraq. She is 59 years old, married, and has 3 children. Kuwaytiya helps her husband with providing the family income.

Kuwaytiya is a tailor and works from home. She has much experience in tailoring women's and children's outfits and has been practicing this profession since 2010. Kuwaytiya is well-known in the neighborhood and has an excellent reputation.

Kuwaytiya is requesting a loan of 2,700 USD. She will use this loan to buy 2 new sewing machines. She is aiming to grow her business and increase her profits so she may provide a better income for her family.

loans.use: to buy two new sewing machines.

loans.name: Ovsanna

texts.en:
Ovsanna is from Lor village in the Syuniq region. She lives with her husband, her daughter (11 years old, in the photo) and two sons (13 and 1 years old, the elder son is in the photo). Ovsanna and her husband work in the village school. Unfortunately, their salaries are not enough to meet the family's needs. 

To be able to cover their basic needs, Ovsanna is engaged in cattle breeding cattle, sheep, and hens, as well as in beekeeping and in cultivation of beech nuts, potatoes, apples, pears, and walnuts. Ovsanna's husband helps her to sell the agricultural products in the local market. As their needs are growing day by day, Ovsanna needs to expand her agribusiness to be able to meet her family's needs more effectively. A loan of 2,000 USD will help her reach her goal, enabling her to purchase three calves and to buy some feed for them. Ovsanna and her family members greatly rely on the goodwill of lenders and will be thankful for their support.

loans.use: to purchase three calves and to buy some feed for them.

loans.name: Jerline

texts.en: Jerline is 38 years old, and she has a table where she sells goods such as oil, rice, coal and pepper in the Paynesville South area of Liberia. This is a suburb of the capital city of Monrovia and one of the most populated areas in Montserrado County.  The area boasts one of the best standards of living in the county with affordable rents, good roads, access to water and lots of transportation options. She is married with a 17-year-old child. She has been in her current business for two years, and started it with money given to her by her husband. She enjoys her business because it gives her additional income to spend.  She sells six days a week, from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m., and is requesting a loan to buy more goods to sell, such as oil, rice, coal and pepper. In the future, she plans to build a house and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more goods such as oil, rice, coal and pepper to sell.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah is 20 years old and single with no children. She runs a fish business in Tombo, a western rural area in Sierra Leone. She started this business to get her daily living. 

She's been in this business since just after the war, and sells fish within her community. She says that her main problem for her business is the scarcity in fish when weather conditions are very poor.

Hannah requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more fish to sell. 

She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and have a permanent business location. 

In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa is 39 years old and lives in Paynesville, which is one of the populated areas in Montserrado County. She is married and her husband is a technician. They have a 13-year-old child, who is currently in school and lives at home. 

For the past 10 years she has been selling chairs for children, sugar, coal, bananas, etc. in the local market. She makes a lot of profit and has more customers so she is requesting a loan to purchase more chairs, sugar, coal, bananas, etc. for her business. Her plans are to build a house and educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase more chairs, sugar, coal, bananas, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase items such as drinks, mayonnaise, ketchup, and sugar

loans.name: Kousar's Group

texts.en:
Kousar is a 52-year-old married woman living in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She has requested a loan for her sons’ fruit-selling business. 

Her two sons own a fruit shop in a nearby town; both are equally participating in the household expenses. They have grown older and have gotten a lot of experience in the fruit-selling business. Now they know the fruit market rates, wholesalers, and how to take care of the customers. So, they want to establish a new separate fruit shop near their house, so that they could earn money and could look after the household expenses as well. 

Therefore, Kousar requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner so that her sons could buy the fresh fruits for their new shop. 

She wants to save the profit amount so that she could arrange the marriages of her sons. She hopes that this loan will prove productive for the enterprise, and she will save a reasonable amount soon.

Kousar is very thankful to Kiva and its field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy fresh fruits for resale.

loans.name: Tenneh

texts.en:
Tenneh is 30 years old and lives in the West Point area which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is single and has three children ages 3, 9, and 12. Her children are attending school and living at home.  She described herself as a hardworking woman. 

Over the past three years she has been running a shop where she sells tea, bread, and fried eggs around the local market, and spends 10 hours each day. She likes her business because of the popularity she has achieved over the years. She started this business with money given to her by her mother; she uses a taxi every time to buy her goods. 

Martha has requested a 20,000 LRD loan to purchase more bread, Lipton's tea, milk, eggs, coffee, mayonnaise, butter, etc. for her business. She plans to build a house and become a big businesswoman.  She would like to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase more bread, Lipton's tea, milk, eggs, coffee, mayonnaise, butter, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more rice, palm oil, pepper, Vita, fish and other items to expand her business,
